plants.name: Crocus vernus
plants.description: A bulbous perennial plant known for its vibrant, cup-shaped flowers that signal the arrival of early spring. Often one of the first flowers to bloom as snow melts, making it a cheerful sight in gardens and wild meadows.
plants.location: Temperate regions of Europe and North America
plants.funFact: Crocus flowers were historically used to produce saffron, a valuable spice, though the culinary saffron comes from Crocus sativus, a related species.

plants.name: Helleborus niger
plants.description: An evergreen perennial with large, white to pale pink bowl-shaped flowers that bloom in late winter to early spring, often pushing through snow. Popular in shade gardens and woodland settings.
plants.location: Mountainous regions of Europe, especially the Alps
plants.funFact: Despite the name 'Christmas Rose', it commonly blooms around spring in milder climates and is prized for winter garden color.

plants.name: Banksia integrifolia
plants.description: A coastal Australian tree famous for its cylindrical flower spikes composed of hundreds of tiny individual flowers, attracting nectar-feeding birds and insects.
plants.funFact: Banksias are vital for Australian ecosystems, serving as an important food source for nectarivores during periods when few other plants are flowering.

plants.name: Narcissus pseudonarcissus
plants.description: A spring-flowering wildflower with pale yellow trumpet-shaped flowers. It is often found in meadows, woodland edges, and grasslands, heralding the start of spring in Europe.
plants.funFact: Narcissus species contain toxic alkaloids which deter herbivores, and they are associated mythologically with the Greek tale of Narcissus.
